metadata.name: European 4-in-1
metadata.description: The most common chainmail weave, dating back over 2000 years. Each ring connects to exactly 4 others, creating a flexible mesh pattern.
metadata.history: Used extensively in medieval European armor, this weave provided excellent protection while maintaining flexibility.

steps.title: Start with the Seed Ring
steps.description: Begin with a single closed ring. This will be the center ring that connects to 4 others. Hold it vertically with the opening facing away from you.
tips: Use pre-closed rings for the seed ring
The ring should be positioned flat, laying horizontal

steps.title: Add First Connector Ring
steps.description: Thread an open ring through the seed ring from the front. This ring should lean to the upper-right at approximately 45 degrees. Close the ring after threading.
tips: The new ring passes through the center of the seed ring
Angle it at 45 degrees for proper weave structure

steps.title: Add Second Connector Ring
steps.description: Add another ring through the seed ring, leaning to the upper-left at 45 degrees. It should mirror the first connector on the opposite side.
tips: This ring mirrors the first connector
Both upper rings should be symmetric

steps.title: Add Third Connector Ring
steps.description: Thread a ring through the seed ring on the lower-right, mirroring the upper-right ring. This ring also angles at 45 degrees.
tips: The lower rings mirror the upper rings

steps.title: Complete the 4-in-1 Unit
steps.description: Add the final connector ring on the lower-left. You now have the basic 4-in-1 unit: one center ring connected to exactly 4 others arranged symmetrically around it.
tips: To make a sheet, connect multiple units by their outer rings
